citations.narrative:
During the inspection process, APHIS inspectors observed a facility employee stop a facility tour vehicle to place feed
inside an enclosure housing 2 zebu, 2 goats, 6 pigs, 3 emus, 4 ducks, and 5 geese to allow facility patrons to more
closely visualize the animals. The animals within the enclosure were not included in the facility’s acquisition records.
Records of acquisition to include information about the animals and the source of the animals are necessary to allow for
legal and medical tracking of the animals. The facility shall make and keep records which fully and correctly disclose all
the required acquisition information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired and in their possession/under their
control including any offspring born.
Correct by: 07/23/2025

The Barn Owl and the Harris’s Hawk enclosure had walls with exposed damaged plywood that was not able to be
effectively cleaned and sanitized. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that all surfaces in contact
with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with 3.158 or be replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by: 07/23/2025

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The interior walls of the primary enclosures housing an adult Harris’s hawk and Barn owl have several large areas,
approximately 2x3 feet, coated with an accumulation of bird excrement. Accumulations of excreta and other material can
harbor microorganisms that could cause animal illness. The applicant must ensure that primary enclosures for birds are
sanitized as often as necessary to prevent such accumulations and other disease hazards
Correct by: 07/24/2025
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by Aug 20 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
During the inspection process, APHIS inspectors observed a facility employee stop a facility tour vehicle to place feed 
inside an enclosure housing 2 zebu, 2 goats, 6 pigs, 3 emus, 4 ducks, and 5 geese to allow facility patrons to more 
closely visualize the animals. The animals within the enclosure were not included in the facility’s acquisition records. 
Records of acquisition to include information about the animals and the source of the animals are necessary to allow for 
legal and medical tracking of the animals. The facility shall make and keep records which fully and correctly disclose all 
the required acquisition information for all animals purchased or otherwise acquired and in their possession/under their 
control including any offspring born.  
Correct by: 07/23/2025 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The Barn Owl and the Harris’s Hawk enclosure had walls with exposed damaged plywood that was not able to be 
effectively cleaned and sanitized. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that all surfaces in contact 
with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with 3.158 or be replaced when worn or soiled. 
Correct by: 07/23/2025 
3.158(b)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The interior walls of the primary enclosures housing an adult Harris’s hawk and Barn owl have several large areas, 
approximately 2x3 feet, coated with an accumulation of bird excrement. Accumulations of excreta and other material can 
harbor microorganisms that could cause animal illness. The applicant must ensure that primary enclosures for birds are 
sanitized as often as necessary to prevent such accumulations and other disease hazards 
Correct by: 07/24/2025 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant.

All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by Aug 20 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
